content.description: Shelf start to edges to crack. #108 on the Marty Pocket Map.
content.location: Northwest, uphill from Pencil Thin Boulder.

content.description:
Karabin's pocket guide calls it V3(TR) due to the (at the time) bad landing. Problem was later retro bolted and subsequently chopped. 

  Problem is the furthest left problem on the boulder. Start low move to rail, somewhat beta intensive crux on sharp holds followed by a big reach to a crimp rail. Keep your head together and top out on jugs.
content.protection: Easily TR via 2 bolt anchor on top. Or Pads and spotters will get you up this classic highball.
content.location: Problem lies on the South end of the Lower Main Area.   Walk off south.

content.description:
Start on nice hold with a foot chip around right corner and left foot smears the chin. Work way up crack, 4-5 moves total. Don't use holds to the left of the crack (this turns into a different, harder route). 

  The moves feel natural and have adequate feet, however the route is short and generic in a way, making it okay.
content.protection: Pad - there is broken glass on ground
content.location:
I haven't seen any routes on this site that use the boulder, though guides might have it. I have attached a gps location. Look for a rock with a horn on top. 

  Same location as Beer Belly and Sharpie.

content.description:
There was some chalk on one of the start holds. I didn't find the route on MP, but I believe it's established starting in the mid-crack area.

  Start on two sidepulls: the left is good, right is sharp and shallow.  

  The feet are awkward for the first move, smear left and jam right foot against a large crack towards the right. Work your way up the crack using two main crimps which you can make your own creative ways to get to.  

  There's a decent hold around the left corner, which will help you get to the pinch block on top of the boulder, which aids with top out. 

  The start + first couple of moves are in the V2-V3 range, while the rest of the route is around a V1.
content.protection: Pad - there is broken glass. The short boulder behind your back shouldn't be a concern unless you're crossing dynamically.
content.location:
I haven't seen any routes on this site that use the boulder, though guides might have it. I have attached a gps location. Look for a rock with a horn on top. 

  Same location as Short N' Easy and Beer Belly.

content.description: A cool highball problem. Use the arete and thin feet to get to the top. You probably wouldn't want to fall off of this.
content.location: Up and left of the Fear Rock. You can either scramble up to it, or the best way might be to take the trail that goes up the saddle turning right on the trail towards the peak and doing a little down climbing.

content.description:
If you're digging a little mantle on an easier route, this is it. 

  Start on big horizontal plate with hidden crimps. Work your way up to a nice but awkward right crimp. Get a foot on the plate and use a reverse sidepull with your left hand. Go up right again, get feet up, and go for a tough top out.  

  I would say the moves (except top out) would be considered V1 difficulty, however the crimps are a little mean for a beginner. That, along with the awkward top out, makes up the V2 section. 

  It's a 4-5 move route and the holds are in awkward positions. It's a good challenge and change of pace, but is quite short of a classic route.
content.protection: None needed. A pad is nice.
content.location: Split Boulders. It's just to the right of Wolf Jr. See pic for location. On the same boulder as Wolf Jr. and same area as Assorted Goods.

content.description: Sit start low on the horizontal rail, first move is out right to the horn of the rail. Reach up left hand to the right most crimp on the upper rail, get high feet, and make a slabby move or two to top out and gain the top. The spirit of the route is to use only the right most crimp, and to stay away from the tempting crack up top, stay balanced and go straight up, but it don't matter. Just climb!
content.protection: Pads and an attentive spotter. Punting off the slab could be the beginnings of back rehab.
content.location: When approaching from 20th St, walk to the up the hill and towards the south side. As you scramble around the corner, you'll see the backside of the boulder. Should be obvious as only a few boulders in this area top 10 feet.

content.description: Low sit start. Left on crimp jug, right on crimp bulb. Top-out above start.
content.location: Past Pencil Thin boulder. Down the tiny hill.

content.description:
Start on the right crack (same as Short N' Easy). Bump right hand up to next jug. Stretch left to grab the lip of the lower belly (the left crack). Work left hand up, move right foot up, and utilize some holds of choice to get to the 'horn'.  

  Top of the boulder is off except horn (can't use  top of right side and traverse over). 

  I would say this route is between good and great (2.5 stars), overall being a great route but due to the restrictive beta (no topping out) and shortness it isn't the best problem.
content.location:
I haven't seen any routes on this site that use the boulder, though guides might have it. I have attached a gps location. Look for a rock with a horn on top. 

  Same location as Short N' Easy and Sharpie.
